Microstructural studies and bonding strength of pressureless sintered nano-silver joints on silver, direct bond copper (DBC) and copper substrates aged at 300 C
S.T. Chua, K.S. Siow*

* Corresponding author. E-mail address: kimsiow@ukm.edu.my (K.S. Siow)

a b s t r a c t
Sintered Ag joint is a potential Pb-free die attach materials for power electronics because of its high operating temperature, high electrical and thermal conductivity as well as its thermo-mechanical reliability. While the long term reliability of the pressure assisted nano-Ag joint has been studied extensively, the performance of pressureless nano-Ag joint during long-term reliability remains a question. In this paper, we addressed the reliability gaps in this area by characterizing the evolution of porosity and microstructures of the pressureless sintered nano-Ag joints on Cu, direct bond copper (DBC) and Ag plated substrates during their high-temperature storage in air at 300 C. The die shear strength of the nano-Ag joint on DBC substrate maintained above 5 MPa for 1000 h of thermal aging while those formed on Cu substrate fell below 5 MPa after 50 h of thermal aging. The microstructure of the sintered nano-Ag joint showed Cu oxide accumulated at the sintered Ag and Cu interface, and upon reaching the critical thickness, they would weaken the sintered nano-Ag joints for the Cu substrate. This microstructure differed from those formed on the Ag plated substrate which showed void-less diffusion band to improve or maintain the die-shear strength. Nano-Ag joints on the DBC substrate also shared similar resilience because of their matching coefficient of thermal expansions with the Cu oxides. The initial increase of die shear strength could be attributed to the densification of the sintered silver joints in terms of the total volume of porosity, pore size and pore shape distribution. The relationship between the oxidation kinetics of Cu, aging time and shear strength were also established to predict the reliability strength of sintered nano-Ag joints on DBC and Ag substrates. In the case of DBC, its rough surface provided additional anchoring to the sintered Ag joint, resulting in a higher die shear strength despite prolonged aging. These favourable results suggested that pressureless nano-Ag joint could perform as well as pressure assisted nano-Ag joint during the long-term reliability test.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Power electronics and devices are essential technologies to enable an efficient electrical energy distribution, usage and generation [1]. In the last few years, wide bandgap (WBG) i.e. silicon carbide and gallium nitride semiconductors are replacing siliconbased semiconductor for the higher performance and temperature applications in the field [2,3]. The operating temperature of these WBG packages needs to be elevated to more than 200 C to realize the full potential of this technology [1e3]. One of the critical
.
interconnections mentioned thereof is the die attach joint. Conventional die attachmaterials for semiconductor packaging, such as reflowed PbSnAg or SnAg solders, suffer from poor mechanical, electrical and thermal properties, intermetallic formation, and their low homologous temperatures prevent them from operating at temperatures above 200 C [4e6].
Hence, low temperature joining technique (LTJT), using micronsized silver (Ag) particle [7e9] and Ag nanoparticles [10e13], has emerged as a potential replacement for these reflowed solders because of its ability to attain the melting temperature of bulk Ag, high thermal conductivity and thermo-mechanical reliability, produced at a relatively low processing temperature [14e16]. Generally, LTJT consists of two different approaches, namely pressureless and pressure-assisted sintering. As its name would suggest,
pressure-assisted sintering involved the application of pressure during the formation of Ag joint. This pressure-assisted sintering requires the use of specialized equipment to avoid cracking the dies during the formation of sintered Ag joint. Hence, there are practical and financial incentives to form the Ag joint by the pressureless sintering route, which is almost similar to the electrically conductive adhesives widely used in the industry.
While the long term reliability of the pressure sintered Ag’s joint is demonstrated commercially [17e19], the performance of pressureless Ag joint remains a question because of various factors involved such as, substrates, sintering profile, sintering atmosphere which affect the microstructure, porosity and interfacial properties of the sintered Ag joints. In addition, sintered Ag joint only forms a reliable joint on Ag-plated or other noble metal plated substrate, even though Cu substrate is the preferred substrate for the packaging of power electronics [20,21].
Hence, several research groups were addressing the reliability issue of power packages produced by pressureless Ag sintering on the Cu substrate [22,23]. Most of their reliability tests were conducted at 150 C, which was lower than the operating temperature of the WBG packages at more than 200 C. They also failed to compare the differences between sintered Ag joints on Cu leadframe and direct bond copper (DBC) substrate during their long term aging studies. Others studied the voids and grain boundaries of the pressureless sintered Ag joint formed on the Ag and Auplated substrates during high-temperature storage at 300 C [24]. They concluded that themicrostructure of sintered Ag on Au and Ag metallization exhibited different evolution of void formation at the joint interface, which led to their different shear strength with storage time [24].
This study addressed the lack of reliability studies in this area by characterizing the evolution of porosity and microstructures of the pressureless sintered Ag joints on Cu, DBC and Ag plated substrates during their high-temperature storage at 300 C. DBC substrates are primarily used by the power module manufacturer while bare Cu is used as leadframe in the packaging of power devices. Differences in surface roughness and coefficients of thermal expansion (CTE) between DBC and Cu substrates also allowed us to study these effects on their reliability during the high-temperature storage testing at 300 C.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental
sections.text:
The nano-sized pressureless Ag paste obtained from the supplier was used in this study, and the typical content of this Ag paste could be referenced here [14]. The average diameters of the Ag nanoparticles were between 10 and 20 nm. The weight percentage of the Ag nanoparticles was approximately 85%. The Ag paste contained 1-decaonol as solvent and alkoxide ligands to prevent nano-sized Ag particle from agglomerating and aggregating. Three substrates selected for this study were Cu, Ag plated Cu (hereafter known as Ag substrate) and direct bond copper (hereafter known as DBC). The selected Si die for this study had a dimension of 2.9 mm 1.8 mm, and its back metallization consisted of Ti/Ni/Ag stack with a total thickness of 2.5 mm.
Nano-Ag pastes were stencil printed on the selected substrates before the Si dies were placed on the as-printed Ag pastes with a scrubbing motion to ensure sufficient contact between silicon back metallization and the faying substrates. In brief, the sintering profile consisted of a peak and soaking temperature at 250 C for 1 h. The entire sintering profile took 2 h to complete in a convection oven filled with 95% N2e5% H2 atmosphere with a flow rate of 100 standard cubic feet per hour. Further details of the nano-Ag paste sintering profile and thermal analysis for optimizing the sintering performance were reported elsewhere [25]. After the sintering was
completed, the samples were thermally aged at 300 C in air atmosphere for 24, 50, 100, 200, 500 and 1000 h before taken out for die-shear and microstructural studies.
The thermally aged samples were molded in epoxy and wetground using sand papers of increasing grits from 400, 600, 800 and 1000 before final polishing with alumina pastes from 6 mm to 1 mm. A control sample was also cross-sectioned as a comparison to the thermally aged samples. All cross-sectional samples were imaged at different magnifications with SEM Hitachi S3400. Point EDX and elemental mapping were also conducted to determine the composition and distribution of the different phases on the nanoAg joint with the X-Max Horiba.
The die shear tests were conducted with the STORM INTELLI 1500 die shearing machine based on criteria as per MIL-STD 883E. Five samples were taken for each treatment time. The data was analyzed using standard one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) with JMP software version 9.0.0. The Tukey-Kramer means comparison, 2 samples t-test, and pooled t-test were used to compute the significance for each test depending on the variance equality of the pairs.
The thickness of the sintered nano-Ag was measured with Hisomet ІІ DH2 depth measuring microscope using the objective lens of PLLWDM40X. The thickness of a sintered nano-Ag joint was determined by measuring and averaging the total thickness of the silicon die and sintered nano-Ag joint at the four corners, before subtracting the die thickness from this total thickness. Five samples were taken for each treatment time.
The porosity of the sintered Ag samples before and after aging for 50 h was imaged and quantified with Image J 1.49 version software. The percentage of porosity was based on the following equation:
Porosity ð%Þ ¼ ðS0=SÞ 100 % (1)
where S is the total cross-sectional area of sintered Ag joints and S0 is the total pore area on the cross-sectioned sample [26]. In addition, the shape form factor (F) of the pore was also used to qualitatively characterize the pore shape based on the following equation:
F ¼ 4pA P2
(2)
where A is the measured pore area and P is the measured pore perimeter [27]. A perfectly round pore has a shape form factor F of 1 while the pore with increasingly irregular shape has a F approaching zero.

sections.heading: 3.1. Die shear strength of nano-Ag joint
sections.text:
High-temperature storage test measures the reliability of the interconnect materials and package. While JEDEC JESD22-A103E recommends the storage temperature for the common power device package, there are no commonly agreed standards for the power module [28]. Hence, publicly available results for the hightemperature storage tests used different aging temperatures such as 175 C [29], 200 C [30], 250 C [30], 350 C [31] and 500 C [32]. Here, we selected 300 C to be our storage temperature as a compromise to accelerate the aging of the sintered nano-Ag joints, and study the evolving porosity and microstructure during this period. Fig. 1A shows the different shear strength of the nano-Ag joints on three substrates (i.e. Ag, Cu and DBC) during air aging at 300 C for the duration of 1000 h Fig. 1B shows the corresponding
thickness of the nano-Ag joint sintered on the three substrates during the same duration of thermal aging at 300 C.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Ag substrate
sections.text: As mentioned earlier, Ag substrate provided the best sintering interfaces for the nano-Ag paste because of their similarity in atomic spacing. Surprisingly, the initial die shear strength of nanoAg joints was similar for the Ag substrate, Cu substrate, and DBC. This similarity in die-shear strength could be attributed to the initial good contact between the silicon dies and the substrates, and the optimized sintering profile which reduced any outgassing that could separate the silicon dies from the substrates. Subsequent high-temperature storage at 300 C for more than 50 h increased the die shear strength of the Ag joint on the Ag substrate to an average of 30 MPa. In Fig. 1B, the thickness of the sintered nano-Ag on Ag substrate was reducing which could be attributed to the consolidation and reduction of the pores, shown in Figs. 2 and 3, resulting in an increase of die shear strength. These increase of die shear strengthwith agingwas consistent with those reported in the literature for nano-Ag joint sintered on Ag or Au-plated substrates [24].

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Cu and DBC substrates
sections.text:
Cu represents an important surface to be sintered because of their application as Cu leadframe and DBC in the packaging of power devices. The sintered nano-Ag joint on our Cu substrates showed deterioration in the die shear strength after thermal aging for more than 50 h. As a comparison, nano-Ag joint on DBC substrate did not show any reduction of die shear strength, but instead increased and maintained their die shear strength for the duration of 500 h at 300 C. When the thermal aging reached 1000 h, the die shear strength of the nano-Ag joint on DBC substrate reduced to 8.5 MPa, which still exceeded the minimum 5 MPa specified in the MIL-STD 883E standard.
The lower CTE mismatch between DBC and silicon dies could explain the relatively higher die shear strength than those nano-Ag joint sintered on the Cu substrate. The CTEs of Cu, alumina (DBC) and silicon dies are 17 ppm/ C, 7 ppm/ C and 2.7 ppm/ C respectively. Another factor which could explain the reliability of the nano-Ag joint sintered on the DBC over the Cu substrate was their differences of interfacial microstructure, which will be discussed in Section 3.2.2 and 3.2.3.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Ag substrate
sections.text:
Fig. 2AeE shows the microstructural changes at the interfacial regions of the nano-Ag joints on Ag substrates after aging at 300 C for 24 h, 50 h, 500 h and 1000 h. The as-sintered nano-Ag joint has the characteristics of nanostructured materials with minuscule and homogeneous voids distributed throughout the nano-Ag joints, but with good bonding to the Ag substrate. The good bonding of Ag nanoparticles to the Ag substrate could be attributed to the high standard free energy for Ag oxide formation [33]. The Ag oxide on the Ag substrate decomposed during the sintering cycle, to form bonds with the Ag nanoparticles [34]. Such characteristics contributed to the high initial die shear strength similar to the initial die shear strength of nano-Ag on the Cu and DBC substrates.
During the thermal aging, ambient oxygen permeated through the Ag plating to oxidize the base Cu substrate. Outlaw andworkers suggested that the permeability (K) of oxygen atoms through a high purity Ag membrane obeys the following equation [35]:
K ¼ 1:01 1018 exp 21870 RT cm 1 s 1 (3)
where R is gas constant (1.987 cal K 1 mol 1), T is the temperature in Kelvin, Ea (21,870 cal/mol) is activation energy. Although the experiment for Eq. (3) was carried out in the temperature range of 400 Ce800 C, we estimated that the oxygen atom permeability through our Ag plating to be 4.63 109 cm 1 s 1 by extrapolating the value to 300 C. In addition, Eq. (3) was developed for large Ag grain, and our Ag plating was likely to have smaller grain size, and an increased oxygen permeability because of the increased number of grain boundaries to allow the diffusion of oxygen through the Ag plating to form the Cu oxides [35].
The voids at the center of the sintered nano-Ag joints, after 24 and 50 h of thermal aging could be attributed to the volatilization of organic binders from the nano-Ag pastes. These voids acted as stress concentrators to lower the die shear strength. Based on Fig. 2D, E, there were no distinct phases between the Cu oxides and sintered nano-Ag after 500 h and 1000 h of thermally aging at 300 C. Both phases appeared to blend into solid solutions without any pores, and such microstructure contributed to the high die shear strength.
Fig. 3 shows that the Cu oxides were accumulating and penetrating the Ag plating, and similar observation has been reported elsewhere [36]. Besides the continuous single-phase Cu oxide
shown in Fig. 3, Ag substrate formed a diffusion band with the Cu oxides. This void-less diffusion band between Cu oxide and Ag layer could have contributed to the high die shear strength of the Ag joint after thermal aging for 1000 h.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Cu substrate
sections.text:
The as-sintered nano-Ag joint was free from any formation of Cu oxides because of the forming gas atmosphere during sintering. Minuscule voids or porosities, as shown in Fig. 4A were similar to those reported here [20,25,37].
The close contact between sintered nano-Ag and Cu substrate at the interfacial regions ensured initial die shear strength to be as high as 17.1 MPa. During the thermal aging in air atmosphere, Cu oxide accumulated at these interfacial regions, as depicted in Fig. 4B, C. Similar to nano-Ag joint on Ag substrate, the formation of Cu oxide increased the contact area of sintered nano-Ag on the Cu substrate. The diffusion of Cu into the sintered nano-Ag formed a continuous layer of Cu oxide during the thermal aging. Similar
formation of complicated diffusion bands of Cu oxides were reported elsewhere, during thermal aging of sintered Ag joints on Cu substrates at 250 C for 72 h [22]. It is likely that our continuous layer of Cu oxide did not reach the critical thickness to induce substantial thermal stress to reduce the die shear strength during the first 50 h of thermal aging. Instead, this detrimental thermal stress was offsetted by the increase in strength as a result of the consolidation of pores, as shown in Fig. 4, and the thickness reduction of the sintered Ag joint shown in Fig 1B.
After thermal aging for 100 h, the cross sectional view in Fig. 4D shows separation at the interfaces between sintered nano-Ag from the Cu oxide, and Cu oxide from the Cu substrate. The CTE mismatches between Cu oxides, sintered nano-Ag joints and silicon dies caused the interfacial de-bonding of these three phases [38]. The formation of Kirkendall voids near the Cu oxide/Cu interface could exacerbate this interfacial separation [39]. After 200 h of thermal aging (Fig. 4E), the delamination of the Cu oxide from the Cu substrate reduced the die shear strength to 1 MPa. Residual
bonding for the nano-Ag joint aged for 100 h, as shown in Fig. 4D, could have contributed to the slightly higher die shear strength (i.e. 3 MPa) than those thermally aged for more than 200 h.
Based on Fig. 5 and the corresponding EDX analysis, the empirical formula for the Cu oxide is likely to be copper (I) oxide or cuprous oxide (Cu2O) because the Cu to O ratio is approximately 2:1 at the Cu substrate after 24 h of aging. Cu2O constituted the major components of the copper oxides, and this result was in good agreement with Hu’s observation about the dominance of Cu2O at the oxidation temperature of less than 400 C [40].
Further elemental mapping for Cu and O atoms, shown in Fig. 6D, coincided with the dark layer of Cu oxides shown in Fig. 5A. Elemental O, which was scattered throughout the sintered Ag, could be attributed to the Ag oxide. This elemental mapping also suggested that the Cu diffused into the sintered Ag layer because of their differences in the diffusion coefficients. The diffusion coefficients of Cu atoms into Ag lattice is 1.5 10 12 cm2 s 1 (at 300 C) [41], while the lattice diffusion of Ag tracer diffusion into pure Cu is 8.4 10 15 cm2 s 1 at 455 C [42]. This difference suggested that the Cu atoms diffused faster into the sintered Ag layer than the Ag atoms diffusing into the Cu substrate.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. DBC substrate
sections.text:
Based on Figs.1B and 7, the thermally aged nano-Ag joint on DBC showed the reduction of joint thickness and porosity, and similar strengthening effect as the nano-Ag joints sintered on the Cu and Ag substrates. As shown in Fig. 1A, these sintered Ag joints on the DBC improved and maintained the die shear strength for longer hours of thermal aging than Cu substrate because of the strong interfacial bonding established between the nano-Ag sintered/Cu oxide and Cu oxide/Cu layer (Fig. 7BeE).
These interfacial properties showed that the rough DBC has an interlocking effect compared to the smooth Cu substrate in
maintaining the mechanical properties of sintered nano-Ag joint during the high-thermal aging test. The average roughness (Ra) of our DBC and Cu substrates were 600 ± 40 nm and 70 ± 4 nm respectively. Elsewhere, it has been reported that an increase of substrate roughness, within the Ra range of 50e300 nmwill reduce the die shear strength for a sintered nano-Ag joint in the absence of pressure [43]. In our research, the slight pressure during the initial placement of the silicon dies allowed the nano-sized Ag particles to fill up the geometrical voids of the DBC to ensure sintering and bonding.

sections.heading: 3.3. Growth rate of Cu2O at Ag, Cu, and DBC substrates
sections.text:
Fig. 8A shows the growth of Cu2O thickness for sintered nano-Ag joint on different substrates during high thermal aging at 300 C. The growth rate of Cu2O on Cu and DBC substrates were almost similar after 24 h of aging, with average thickness of 3.71 mm and 3.63 mm for Cu and DBC substrates respectively. These growth rates remained same after aging for 50 h. The thickness of Cu2O on Ag substrate was only 3.14 mm during this period because of the Ag plating hindering the diffusion of oxygen to the base Cu substrate. After 500 h of thermal aging, the Cu2O thickness on DBC substrate was 59% thicker than Ag substrate. At 1000 h, the difference was 54% thicker on the DBC substrate than those formed on the Ag substrate. The Cu2O growth rate at 300 C was likely to be dominated by the grain boundaries diffusion, similar to those proposed by Mimura et al. for oxidation between 350 C and 500 C [44].
Based on Figs. 2, 4, and 7, the growth of Cu2O occupied the central volume of the sintered nano-Ag layer which could lead to an early mechanical, thermal or electrical failure in the die-attach joint. Hence, it is useful to compute the percentage of Cu2O growth occupying sintered nano-Ag layer by normalizing the Cu2O thickness by its bondline thickness. During this calculation, the
thickness of Ag metallization from the die backside metallization (i.e. 2 mm)was subtracted from the thickness of bond line. However, the Ag plating thickness of 5 mm ± 0.2 mm for the Ag substrate was included into the calculation of bond line thickness because of the close proximity to the newly formed Cu2O.
Fig. 8B plots the percentage of the normalized Cu2O thickness on the sintered nano-Ag joint during the high-temperature storage test at 300 C in air. Ag-plated substrate appeared to have the lowest percentage of normalized Cu2O thickness because of the dense Ag plating hindering the diffusion of oxygen. In the initial stage of thermal aging (i.e. 24 h and 50 h), 20% of the bondline thickness were Cu2O for the sintered Ag joint on the Ag substrate. The initial Cu2O growth was slow, as predicted by the parabolic law of Cu oxide kinetics [45]. At this stage, the build-up of Cu2Owas still confined within the Ag plating thickness. The normalized Cu2O thickness increased when thermal aging exceeded 50 h, but the percentage was still lower than those formed on DBC, as shown in Fig. 8B.
Unlike Fig. 8A, the normalized Cu2O thickness, in Fig. 8B, was able to distinguish the influence of surface roughness present on the Cu and DBC substrate on the die shear strength. DBC had localized bondline thicknesses which were changing based on the peaks and valleys on the surface, as shown in Fig. 7B. The normalized Cu2O thickness was a function of bondline thickness; higher bond line thickness in the valley, contributed to the lower percentage of Cu2O growth and vice versa, which in turn contributed to higher variation of Cu2O in the DBC substrate. As shown in Fig 8, the rough DBC slowed down the growth of Cu2O compared to those sintered Ag joints formed on the Cu substrate. On DBC substrate, the Cu2O grew rapidly from 24 to 500 h of thermal aging at a rate of 0.1% per hour, and this nano-Ag joint maintained its integrity even though the normalized Cu2O thickness reached 77% at 500 h of thermal aging. Sign of deteriorating shear strength was visible when the Cu2O occupied 84% of the die-attach regions at 1000 h of thermal aging but the shear strength was still above the minimum die shear strength of 5 MPa, as specified in the MIL-STD 883E
standard. This resilience in the die shear strength on DBC substrate could be attributed to the different CTEs of these multilayer stacks; CTE of DBC (alumina), Cu oxides and Ag are 7 ppm/ C, 4.3 ppm/ C
and 19.5 ppm/ C respectively. Fig. 9 shows the shear strength of the sintered nano-Ag joint is not negatively correlated with the Cu2O thickness or the
normalized Cu2O thickness, as opposed to Lee et al. work with Cu/ polyimide interface [46]. The latter reported the void formation at the Cu2O/Cu interface increased with Cu2O layer growth, and these voids were responsible for the deterioration of the bonding strength. On the contrary, the shear strength of the sintered nanoAg joint coincided with increasing Cu2O growth to reach the maximum, before the shear strength started to deteriorate again. This correlation was fortuitous and more aptly attributed to the reduction of overall porosity and big pore sizes as well as the dominance of circular pores, which will be discussed in Section 3.4. Based on Figs. 2BeE and 7BeE, the sintered nano-Ag joints show limited void formation at the Cu2O/DBC and Cu2O/Ag interfaces. These characteristics allowed the possibilities of controlling the Cu2O growth to achieve the desired mechanical strength of the sintered nano-Ag joint during the thermal aging.
The classical parabolic rate law of metal oxidation kinetics is often employed to describe the formation of metal oxides at high temperature [45]. At low and intermediate temperature, the
oxidation rate law of Cu follows a parabolic, logarithmic, cubic dependence [47] or a generalized power law, as shown in Eq. (4).
xn ¼ kt (4)
where x is the equivalent thickness of the oxide film, t is the time, k and exponent n are constants. Alternatively, Eq. (4) can be expressed in another form as shown in Eq. (5).
x ¼ k0tm (5)
where k’ and time exponent m were constants, and m ¼ 1/n. The Cu2O thickness of the sintered nano-Ag joint on the Ag and DBC substrate fitted well with the power law described in Eq. (5), and these curve-fitting were exemplified in Fig. 10A and B respectively. The relationship between the normalized Cu2O thickness, Poxide in sintered nano-Ag and aging time (in hrs) could also be fitted with the power law in Eq. (5) by replacing the dependent variable x with Poxide. The curve-fittings of Poxide for sintered nano-
Ag on Ag and DBC substrates are shown in Fig. 10C, D respectively. The R2 adjusted values for all the fitted curves in Fig. 10 exceeds 85%, and these values are summarized in Table 1. The time exponent constant m of Cu2O thickness for Ag and DBC substrates were not 0.5 inferring that the oxidation kinetics of Cu was not following the parabolic rate law. Oxidation kinetics of Cu substrates which
conformed to the parabolic rate law was often conducted on bare Cu plates at oxidation temperatures of more than 300 C [44,48]. In comparison, our samples consisted of nano-Ag sintered Cu substrates at an aging temperature of 300 C. The time exponent, m of Cu2O thickness, x and the normalized Cu2O thickness, Poxide for DBC substrate were higher than those on Ag substrate, indicating Cu2O
grew at a faster rate on the DBC substrate. These values coincided with our observation that the growth rate of Cu2O on the DBC substrates was higher than those on the Ag substrates.
The initial Ag plating on the Ag substrate could also be another reason for the exponent m to be lower than those on the DBC substrate. The proposed Cu oxidation kinetics information in Table 1 can serve as a reference for further simulation study to model the Cu2O growth and predict the reliability of the sintered nano-Ag joint at high-temperature storage application of 300 C.

sections.heading: 3.4. Porosity, pore size and pore shape distribution
sections.text:
As mentioned earlier, porosity is an important property of the sintered Ag joints because of its influence on the mechanical, thermal and electrical properties of the Ag joints [16]. Hence, there is a need to carefully analyze and characterize its evolution with aging time.
Fig. 11A shows the porosity evolution of the sintered nano-Ag
joints before and after 50 h of air aging at 300 C. Our image analysis showed that the porosity ranged from 10% to 13% before aging, and these values coincided with published results [24]. After thermal aging for 50 h, the percentage of porosity reduced to values ranging from 2% to 3.5%, as shown in Fig. 11A, and this percentage also coincided with others [24]. When the thermal aging time increased, porosity decreased because of the migration of Ag atoms in the diffusion-controlled boundary driven by their grain boundary energy [49].
Stresses arising from oxidation has been demonstrated by others [50]; Appleby and workers suggested the doming effect to relieve the stress originating from Cu oxidation [51]. Since the CTE for Ag, Cu oxide and Cu were 19.5 ppm/ C, 4.3 ppm/ C [51] and 17 ppm/ C respectively, the doming would lean towards the direction of sintered nano-Ag when thermally aged at 300 C. Furthermore, another study on the growth of Cu oxide at the Cu/ polyimide interface showed that the Cu atoms diffused out of Cu layer into polyimide to react with the atmospheric oxygen to form
Cu2O at Cu/polyimide interface [46]. The same study also showed that the Cu foil was slightly displaced upwards upon the formation of Cu2O at the Cu/polyimide interface to compensate for the reduction of Cu thickness.
The formation of Cu2O into the sintered nano-Ag joint coupled with the doming effect from the stress originating from Cu oxidation displaced the sintered nano-Ag to shrink the pore size. Further thermal aging and grain growth created an increasing number of irregular pore shapes. The porosity of sintered nano-Ag on Ag substrate was slightly lower than those formed on Cu and DBC substrate, regardless of thermal history. The extra Ag plating could be beneficial to reduce porosity during sintering and aging process because of the additional plated Ag available for grain growth process. Since the percentage of porosity before and after thermal aging on Cu and DBC substrates were equivalent, the surface roughness of the Cu substrate was not an important factor to affect the evolution of porosity formed in the sintered Ag joints.
Fig. 11B shows the densification of the sintered nano-Ag in terms of the pore size distribution during air aging at 300 C for 50 h. The pore sizes in the sintered nano-Ag ranged from 0.03 to 2.33 mm2. The pore sizes were divided into three groups, group A small pores (0.03 mm2e0.16 mm2), group B medium pores (0.16 mm2 to 0.8 mm2) and group C large pores (larger than 0.8 mm2), similar to those reported by Fu et al. [26]. The sintered nano-Ag joint consisted of mainly group A pore size, followed by group B pore size, as shown in Fig. 11B. The distribution of large pore size like group C on each substrate was less than 3% of the
total pore counts. After thermal aging the sintered nano-Ag joint for as short as 50 h, the group A small pores increased significantly and at the same time group B medium pores decreased in number regardless of the substrate used; this phenomenon is caused by neck growth in the sintered Ag joint [49]. Hence, thermal aging improved the mechanical properties of sintered nano-Ag because of the reduction in the large pores.
Fig. 11C shows the computed pore shape factor, F distribution for nano-Ag joint on Cu, Ag and DBC substrate before and after thermal aging at 300 C. Before thermal aging, sintered nano-Ag joint on three substrates exhibited increasing frequency of pore with spherical or near-spherical shape, with the highest frequency at 0.9 and 1.0 pore shape factor. After sintered nano-Ag samples were thermally aged at 300 C, the frequency of irregular pores (F¼ 0.1 to 0.4) increased because of the clustering and segregation of the pores during the grain growth process. Nevertheless, the perfectly spherical pores (F ¼ 1.0) still constituted the largest fraction of the pores to maintain the structural integrity of the sintered nano-Ag joint since irregular pores were the major stress concentrators compared to round pores.
The qualitative and quantitative measurements of the attained porosity, pore size and pore shape factor distribution proved that the shear strength of sintered nano-Ag joints did not deteriorate but improvewith thermal aging. Hence pressureless sintered nanoAg could serve as a promising replacement for solder die attach in power modules application which required high temperature application during their long hours of service.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
We demonstrated the long term reliability of the pressureless sintered nano-Ag joint on the DBC and Cu substrate, and compared them with Ag substrate in a high-temperature storage test at 300 C. In the case of Ag substrate, the die shear strength increased after aging for more than 50 h. In the case of DBC, die shear strength of the nano-Ag joint was able to show higher die attach strength than Cu substrate by maintaining the strength to be above 5 MPa during the 1000 h of aging while the Ag joints on the Cu substrate fell below 5 MPa after 50 h of thermal aging.
We investigated the microstructural evolution of the crosssectioned sintered nano-Ag joints and discovered the void-less Cu oxides growing at the interfaces between sintered Ag joints and Cu layers for all bonding substrates. These Cu oxides at the interface weakened the sintered nano-Ag joints on Cu substrate because of the different CTEs for Cu oxides, Cu substrate and nano-Ag joints. However, this detrimental effect of the copper oxides was offsetted by the consolidation of the sintered silver joint with reduction in pore sizes and joint thickness in the beginning stage of the aging. This microstructure differed from those formed on the Ag-plated substrate which showed a mixed and void-less diffusion band to provide more strength to the interface. DBC substrates had better matching CTEs with the Cu oxides, and hence, reduced the interfacial thermal stresses of the nano-Ag joints. The overall porosity percentage of the sintered nano-Ag joint decreased with aging time on all three substrates because of the diffusion-controlled boundary migration driven by the grain boundary energy. The pore size distribution of the sintered nano-Ag joint consisted of mainly group A (0.03 mm2e0.16 mm2) pore size, and subsequent aging at 300 C in air further increased the frequency of this group A pore size. In the case of pore shape factor, F distribution, most of the pores were still spherical in shape after aging on all three substrates. The evolution of porosity during high-temperature storage suggested that the mechanical properties sintered nano-Ag could be enhanced during this thermal aging.
The Cu2O growth thickness and the normalized Cu2O thickness with aging time was characterised to elucidate the role of Cu oxidation kinetics in the reliability of the pressureless sintered Ag joint. The shear strength of the sintered nano-Ag joint on Ag and DBC substrates increased with the increase of Cu2O thickness and normalized Cu2O thickness, and achieved peak strength before deteriorating at 1000 h of thermal aging. The Cu oxidation kinetics curve of sintered nano-Ag joint can be modelled using the generalized power law and the attained information proved to be suitable for further simulation to predict the reliability of the sintered nano-Ag during high temperature application.

STC wrote the first draft of the paper while KSS revised the paper for intellectual content and clarity. STC and KSS analyzed and interpreted the data, and agreed on the final manuscript to be submitted.

metadata.abstractText: Sintered Ag joint is a potential Pb-free die attach materials for power electronics because of its high operating temperature, high electrical and thermal conductivity as well as its thermo-mechanical reliability. While the long term reliability of the pressure assisted nano-Ag joint has been studied extensively, the performance of pressureless nano-Ag joint during long-term reliability remains a question. In this paper, we addressed the reliability gaps in this area by characterizing the evolution of porosity and microstructures of the pressureless sintered nano-Ag joints on Cu, direct bond copper (DBC) and Ag plated substrates during their high-temperature storage in air at 300 C. The die shear strength of the nano-Ag joint on DBC substrate maintained above 5 MPa for 1000 h of thermal aging while those formed on Cu substrate fell below 5 MPa after 50 h of thermal aging. The microstructure of the sintered nano-Ag joint showed Cu oxide accumulated at the sintered Ag and Cu interface, and upon reaching the critical thickness, they would weaken the sintered nano-Ag joints for the Cu substrate. This microstructure differed from those formed on the Ag plated substrate which showed void-less diffusion band to improve or maintain the die-shear strength. Nano-Ag joints on the DBC substrate also shared similar resilience because of their matching coefficient of thermal expansions with the Cu oxides. The initial increase of die shear strength could be attributed to the densification of the sintered silver joints in terms of the total volume of porosity, pore size and pore shape distribution. The relationship between the oxidation kinetics of Cu, aging time and shear strength were also established to predict the reliability strength of sintered nano-Ag joints on DBC and Ag substrates. In the case of DBC, its rough surface provided additional anchoring to the sintered Ag joint, resulting in a higher die shear strength despite prolonged aging. These favourable results suggested that pressureless nano-Ag joint could perform as well as pressure assisted nano-Ag joint during the long-term reliability test. © 2016 Elsevier B.V.
